Problem: Damaged STOP Sign
Category: Road Sign
Type: STOP Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 14.4
Recommendation:
The 'STOP' sign, used on Minor Roads intersecting Major Roads, requires vehicles to stop before entering and proceed only when safe. It is octagonal with a red background, a white border, and "STOP" written centrally in white. Installed on the left side of the approach, it should be placed close to the stop line, typically 1.5 m in advance, without impairing visibility of the Major Road. The dimensions vary by approach speed: up to 50 km/h, 750 mm height, 25 mm border, 175 mm font; 51–65 km/h, 900 mm height, 30 mm border, 210 mm font; and over 65 km/h, 1200 mm height, 40 mm border, 280 mm font.

There's a damaged issue with the stop sign. What should be done?

If the stop sign is damaged, it should be fixed according to IRC:67-2022 Clause 14.4. The STOP sign tells vehicles on a minor road to stop before joining a major road. It's octagonal, red, with white lettering, and should be placed about 1.5 m before the stop line so it's clearly visible. Size varies by speed: up to 50 km/h uses 750 mm height, 51-65 km/h uses 900 mm, and over 65 km/h uses 1200 mm.

Problem: Height Issue Minimum Speed Limit Sign
Category: Road Sign
Type: Minimum Speed Limit Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 14.10.6
Recommendation:
Minimum Speed Limit Sign shall be installed to indicate the minimum legal speed. This shall be used on specific sections to avoid the slow moving vehicles acting as a hindrance so as to improve the efficiency of the traffic movement. When installing road signs, it is important to ensure proper clearance and visibility for both vehicles and pedestrians. For kerbed roads, the bottom edge of the lowest sign shall be 2.1 to 2.5 m above the kerb and shall be 2 to 2.5 m above the pavement on roads without kerbs. A minimum headroom of 2.1 m is required for signs above footpaths or pedestrian areas. For multi-lane highways, signs placed on medians for better visibility shall have a minimum clearance of 2.5 m (as per clauses 4.3, 4.4).

There's a height issue with the minimum speed limit sign. What should be done?

If the minimum speed limit sign has a height issue, adjust it per IRC:67-2022 Clause 14.10.6. It should have proper clearance—2.1–2.5 m above the kerb or pavement, and 2.5 m on medians of multi-lane highways to stay visible and safe.

Problem: Faded Hospital Sign
Category: Road Sign
Type: Hospital Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 17.8
Recommendation:
Hospital sign should be used to notify drivers of vehicles that they should take the precautions required near medical establishments and in particular that they should not make any unnecessary noise. The sign also serves to indicate the location of hospital where medical facilities will be available. Sign shall be rectangular and have a blue background, while black symbol shall be displayed in a white square to indicate the facility. The size of the normal sign shall be 600 mm x 800 mm and of the small sized sign 450 mm x 600 mm. On the blue band at the bottom of the sign, the distance to the facility indicated or to entry of the road leading to it, may be inscribed in white. Signs may also be set up at the entry to the road leading to the facility and may then bear a white directional arrow on the blue part at the bottom (as per clause 17.1).

There's a faded issue with the hospital sign. What should be done?

If the hospital sign is faded, repaint or replace it as per IRC:67-2022 Clause 17.8. It warns drivers to stay quiet near hospitals and helps them find nearby medical facilities. The sign is rectangular with blue background, white square with black symbol, sized 600x800 mm (normal) or 450x600 mm (small).

Problem: Spacing Issue U-Turn Ahead Sign
Category: Road Sign
Type: U-Turn Ahead Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 4.8
Recommendation:
When multiple signs need to be placed along the same section of road, care shall be taken to ensure they do not obscure each other. On interurban roads, two successive signs shall be spaced at a minimum distance of 0.6*V m (where V is the design speed in km/h). For urban roads, a minimum distance of 20 m between successive signs shall be maintained.

There's a spacing issue with the u-turn ahead sign. What should be done?

If the u-turn ahead sign spacing is off, reposition signs according to IRC:67-2022 Clause 4.8. Keep 0.6 × V meters apart on interurban roads or at least 20 m apart in urban areas so one sign doesn't block another.

Problem: Improper Placement Gap in Median Sign
Category: Road Sign
Type: Gap in Median Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 15.26
Recommendation:
Gap in Median sign shall be installed ahead of a gap in the median of a divided carriageway, other than at intersection. Signs are normally erected on the left side of the road, but in high-traffic areas, critical locations or where visibility is limited, a second sign may be placed on the right side or median of multilane roads (as per clause 4.8). Placement of Cautionary sign vary with approach speed: up to 50 km/h, clear visibility distance as 45 m placed 45m from the hazard; 51-65 km/h, clear visibility distance as 60 m placed 45-110m from the hazard; 66-80 km/h, clear visibility distance as 70 m placed 110-180m from the hazard; 81-120 km/h, clear visibility distance as 90 m placed 180-245m from the hazard; 121-150 km/h, clear visibility distance as 110 m placed 245-305m from the hazard (as per clause 15.2). Signs shall be 600 mm to 3 m from the shoulder, at least 1 m from the edge on roads without shoulders and minimum 300 mm from the kerb on kerbed roads, ensuring no obstruction (as per clause 4.2).

There's an improper placement issue with the gap in median sign. What should be done?

If the gap in median sign isn't placed properly, reposition it according to IRC:67-2022 Clause 15.26. It should be set before the median gap on divided roads, giving clear warning to drivers. Place on left side normally, or both sides for high-traffic areas. Follow speed-based distances: 45m for up to 50 km/h, 45-110m for 51-65 km/h, 110-180m for 66-80 km/h, 180-245m for 81-120 km/h, and 245-305m for 121-150 km/h.

Problem: Obstruction Crash Prone Area Ahead Sign
Category: Road Sign
Type: Crash Prone Area Ahead Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 11.2
Recommendation:
Drivers and other road users must have a clear and unobstructed view of road signs to ensure safe navigation. The area that shall remain free from obstructions to the sight line, whether caused by vegetation (e.g., bushes, trees), other signs, or street furniture (e.g., crash barriers), is referred to as the clear visibility distance. This distance shall increase as traffic speeds rise to provide sufficient reaction time. Road signs or their supports (including front and back) shall not display any form of advertisement or message unrelated to traffic control (as per clause 2.3).

There's an obstruction issue with the crash prone area ahead sign. What should be done?

If the crash prone area ahead sign is blocked, clear vegetation or other obstructions per IRC:67-2022 Clause 11.2. The clear visibility zone must expand with speed. Also, check that no ads are placed on the sign or its support (Clause 2.3).

Problem: Non-Retroreflective U-Turn Prohibited Sign
Category: Road Sign
Type: U-Turn Prohibited Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 14.6.22
Recommendation:
The 'U-Turn Prohibited' sign indicates areas where vehicles are not allowed to reverse their direction of travel. It should be placed at the start and at intervals along road sections where this restriction is enforced by the controlling authority. The maximum spacing between two successive signs should not exceed 120 meters on each side of the road. The sign is circular with a red border, a red oblique bar, a white background, and a black symbol. Its size depends on design speed: Up to 65 km/h (300 mm* diameter, 35 mm border and oblique bar, 75 mm font; or 600 mm diameter, 50 mm border and bar, 100 mm font), 66–80 km/h (750 mm diameter, 60 mm border and oblique bar, 125 mm font), 81–100 km/h (900 mm diameter, 75 mm border and oblique bar, 150 mm font), 101–120 km/h (1200 mm diameter, 100 mm border and oblique bar, 225 mm font), and 121–150 km/h (1500 mm diameter, 125 mm border and oblique bar, 250 mm font). The retro-reflective sheeting used shall cover the entire surface, be weather-resistant, colorfast, and free from defects, with a minimum coefficient of retro-reflection in accordance with ASTM D 4956 standards. The sign shall be replaced either at the end of the warranty period of the retro-reflective sheeting or if its reflectivity falls below 80 percent of the initial reflectivity (as per clauses 6.7 & 13.3).

There's a non-retroreflective issue with the u-turn prohibited sign. What should be done?

If the u-turn prohibited sign isn't retroreflective, replace it per IRC:67-2022 Clause 14.6.22. Max spacing: 120 m apart. Size varies by speed (300-1500 mm diameter). The sheeting must meet ASTM D 4956 standards and be replaced if reflectivity drops below 80% or warranty expires (Clauses 6.7 & 13.3).

Problem: Height Issue Object Hazard (Left) Sign
Category: Road Sign
Type: Object Hazard (Left) Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 15.66
Recommendation:
Retroreflective Object Hazard (Left) sign is used for roadside hazards on the left side, such as bridge abutments, guard rails or trees encroaching into the roadway. It is specifically intended to warn of hazards located on the left edge of the travelled way. The sign shall be a vertical rectangle of 300 mm x 900 mm. Object Hazard Marker are striped markers with alternating black and yellow stripes sloping downward at an angle of 45° towards the side of the obstruction on which the traffic is to pass. These shall be erected immediately ahead of the line of obstruction and at sufficient height to ensure that these will be properly visible to the oncoming traffic. The inner edge of the OHM shall align with the obstruction's inner edge wherever possible (as per clause 5.1 and 5.2 of IRC:79-2019).

Object Hazard Markers need 45° black/yellow stripes, placed immediately before the obstruction at a height visible to traffic, aligned with the obstruction's inner edge per IRC:79-2019.

Type: Single Chevron (Normal) Sign
Reference: IRC:67-2022 Clause 15.65
Recommendation:
Single Chevron (Normal) signs are used on curved roadways with deflection angle between 20° and 90° and for roads operating less than 100 kmph, to inform drivers about the sharpness of the curve. The sign shall be a vertical rectangle of 500 mm x 600 mm and shall be installed always on the outside of a curve, in line with and at approximately right angle to approaching traffic. Use of a single board of chevron sign for delineating a curve shall be avoided. Spacing of chevron signs shall be such that the road user always has at least two signs in view, until the change in alignment eliminates the need for the sign. The signs shall be visible far enough in advance for drivers to react to the change in alignment.
